message: My go-to headphones are sennheiser HD 595's, but they don't seem to be carried anymore
What kind of issues are you into with your current MacBook?
it's probably mostly related to ram (this gen only came with 1 gb), but I'd rather err on the side of power

Been doing some research and here's what I'm thinking of for a solution:
1 x 15" 2.0 GHz MacBook Pro with 8 GB ram and upgraded display resolution
1 x 15" HengeDock (http://www.hengedocks.com/)
2 x 23" Samsung monitors (http://www.memoryexpress.com/Products/PID-MX28585(ME).aspx)
    - One powered off of mini-display port
    - One powered off a USB display adapter
1 x Some generic wired keyboard
1 x Logitech wireless marathon mouse (http://www.canadapost.ca/shopper/items/3696637/Logitech-M705-910-001935-97855068538)
1 x Headphones (need help here)
I could also consider getting something which is closed to help blocking out any distracting noises when I want to zone in
I use the lowest end 13" MBP. Don't need anything much more insane.
@darkhelmetlive do you know if there's any canadian resellers?
oh yeah i'd go with 8GB of ram for sure
on my current one when I have firefox, chrome (with tons of tabs), iterm, mvim, various other crap like skype, etc. running it starts to get slow
Ruby dev seems pretty lax for requirements.
(Grado is probably one of the best open headphone companies, though they sit on your ear vs around it like the Beyer's, which is better for long term listening, like all day at work)
not extra keyboard/mouse/anything. just my macbook
If you mean for the headphones, go to The Gramaphone: http://www.gramophone.ca/ Bought mine and my Grados from them. They know good audio
hmmmm
Headphones: http://north-america.beyerdynamic.com/shop/hah/headphones-and-headsets/at-home/music-pleasure/dt-440-edition.html These things rock my socks off.
this is for work so I'll be buying a new macbook anyways

no, i live off my 13", and it typically just sits on my lap (at home on the couch) or a table if i have one at hand. i use my desktop (windows, 12GB RAM) for gaming/video conversion and other stuff (not doing much windows dev lately)

@darkhelmetlive do you run some form of docking station on your MBP?  I've been using my 13" for a while here and it's mostly okay, but I find myself going back to my desktop whenever I need to do any research or documentation

I've been meaning to get to the new gramophones location anyways; maybe I'll head there this weekend.  What I love about my HD 595's is that not only is the sound amazing, but the super aural cups are velvet padded.  It's like putting a soft kitten around your ears.

When I spec'd my dev box for Firenest (mostly PHP in Netbeans), I thought I could back off on the specs because it didn't seem like it would need much, but when I'm dev'ing every little delay on an alt-tab or a virtual desktop switch or whatever adds a little frustration and makes it that much harder to stay in the flow.
just curious, does anybody run VMware fusion & VS2010?  how are you finding it?

My buddy at work uses VM Fusion at work with VS 2010, he hasn't run into any issues that I know of. It's actually pretty amazing how well it works. I didn't believe him when he first told me about it.
Actually, a lot of .NET guys use MBP/VMware Fusion/VS2008.  The last bit of feedback I got was that VS2010 was a bit slow on MBP/VMware Fusion (but that is probably VS2010).
I enjoy my 15" MacBook Pro. No need for extra monitors or any other peripherals... except for a magic mouse.
Even though I'm the Ubuntu guy, I'm going to get  a 15 MBP when this computer dies and then dual-boot with Ubuntu and Mac OS. It's hard to knock the quality of the MBP hardware.
Has anyone tried out http://pow.cx/ on the Mac? Looks like an interesting dev server.
@MarkBennett Pow is on my todo list.

@topgenorth I just retired my first MBP that I bought in 2006.  The only hardware issue that I ever had is that the batteries had to be replaced every 18 months or so.  And it was damn hot on the bottom.  But other than that it was a fantastic machine and I didn't hesitate to get a new one.

Speaking of quality:  How many of you have had hardware issues with your MBP?  I ask because the last time I was looking at the laptops (almost 5 years ago), I didn't know a single MBP owner (about 5 of my friends/colleagues) who didn't have some issue that required their MBP to be sent back.  And the 2007 MBP15 that I borrowed seems to have some hardware challenges now too.
@MarkBennett I'm just starting to play with pow and I haven't had any issue with any of the Rails3 apps that I've tried.

There was a generation of MacBook Pro's that got hit by Nvidia's PBGA issue, where almost every laptops graphics would eventually fail and have to be sent back.  Other than that I haven't had or seen any issues.
@benzittlau do you know what generation of MBP that would be?  or timeframe?
Hmmmm, I can't remember for sure.  2 or 3 generations back I believe.
